title: 105_s107
content: The "Pension Benefits Fairness Act" may be cited as the short title. Modifications of joint and survivor annuity requirements are included in the Act. Amendments to ERISA include changes to the amount of annuity provided under the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974. This involves offering a qualified joint and survivor annuity option for participants. The amendments to ERISA introduce a qualified joint and survivor annuity option for participants, providing a survivor annuity equal to 67 percent of the annuity payable to the participant while both are alive. Amendments to ERISA introduce a qualified joint and survivor annuity option for participants, requiring terms and conditions to be provided with an illustration of benefits for the participant and spouse to consider before choosing a retirement benefit. Amendments to the Internal Revenue Code specify the amount of the annuity. The ERISA amendments introduce a qualified joint and survivor annuity option for participants, with specific terms and conditions outlined in the Internal Revenue Code. The ERISA amendments introduce a qualified joint and survivor annuity option for participants, with specific terms and conditions outlined in the Internal Revenue Code. The survivor annuity provides 67 percent of the annuity payable to the participant while both are alive, is the actuarial equivalent of a single annuity for the participant's life, and is treated as a qualified joint and survivor annuity for all other purposes. The ERISA amendments introduce a qualified joint and survivor annuity option for participants, effective for plan years beginning after December 31, 1996. This option includes specific terms and conditions outlined in the Internal Revenue Code, with a survivor annuity providing 67 percent of the annuity payable to the participant while both are alive. An illustration of the benefits under each annuity is offered, along with an acknowledgement form to be signed by the participant and spouse before choosing any retirement benefit. The ERISA amendments introduce a qualified joint and survivor annuity option for participants, effective for plan years beginning after December 31, 1996. Employers must ratify the amendments by the first plan year starting on or after January 1, 1999, or the date of the last collective bargaining agreement termination. Plan amendments must be made by the first plan year starting on or after January 1, 1999. The plan must operate in accordance with the new amendment before the first plan year and apply the amendment retroactively. Compliance with this requirement does not mean the plan fails to provide definite benefits or contributions.
